body: @zhangchen-qinyinghua I'm not very familiar with makefiles but there may be easier ways of doing this. Like this one https://github.com/pertusa/mxnet_predict_cc/blob/master/Makefile. Please check if it works for your case
@kayhan-batmanghelich @korneil hasn't been active for a while. You are welcome to pick up where he left off

Linking two other requests for similar functionality:
- https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/868
- https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/762

@piiswrong 
Yeah, like you say, the Makefile could be a lot easier, so I clean it.

However, in my opinion, that way it may become less portable.

For exmeple, -lopenblas only works when the user is using openblas, and in my situation, a -DMSHADOW_USE_CBLAS=1 is also necessary.
And if the user is using a GPU, something like -DMSHADOW_USE_CUDA may be necessary.

Still my Makefile is not portable either, I think add a tail to original Makefile is the best (for portable).
Feel free to modify it if there's better solution.

I see your point. I think we can
1. add a target to root makefile
2. add a unified makefile for all cpp exmaples that include all the flags and options

@hjk41 @mli What do you think

Looks good, thanks
one more question: where is use_ndarray.cpp?
also could you create a subfolder mlp/ under exmaples/cpp and move your files into it? since we can only have one makefile per folder
@piiswrong I think a CMake file is better for portability. We should have a root CMake file for all the cpp examples, so that when other examples are added, they can be easily built.

@zhangchen-qinyinghua I see you already wrapped some layers including FullyConnected and Softmax into C++. Are you interested in make it complete so users can use the C++ interface just as they do with Python?
You'll need to modify the BN layer for that. Compute dataset-wise statistics for mean and std, and use them at test time instead of compute from batch everytime
yes

Hi, all

I am trying the mlp.cpp code and I think it is good and able to be understood and able to compile. However, I met some problems and have no idea how to debug for it. The error is:

Cannot find Operator FullyConnected in registry.

So it should be related with the MXNET_REGISTER_OP_PROPERTY. I checked the code in fully_connected.cc, it should have already been registered.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7029845/11737719/09b7ce58-9faa-11e5-8b8e-6995da5bf734.png)

As you suggested in the doc on how to build a new operator, I tried to REGISTER the FullyConnected in the operator.h file which are included in my project. However it failed to compile, giving the error, unknown Type Error.

I was not familiar with cpp. I have finished a runnable python version, and now I am trying a cpp version for several reasons. So if I could finish the cpp version, it could be a good example for those who are trying cpp.

The whole project should be runnable, I tested with the NDArray example and it is runnable with NDArray. So I believe my C_FLAGS and L_FLAGS are correct and the problem should be REGISTER related. Can you give any suggestions? Thanks a lot.

OK, I have got wrong with the function of metric.
I thought it is response to both evaluation and objective.

I have added a Makefile and README file for help, and move every thing to an independent folder.
Thanks to @pertusa & @piiswrong

Another problem is that I faced a problem when the output vector is 1d.
It raises error.

Thanks @piiswrong , I'll contribute once merged. I've tested the @skylook code, and I get a similar output than with my version, but still very different from the python results. Classifying the vulture image (from my last message) with the ImageNet1K model, I get only a clear peak at the class 904 (window). However, the python script returns a kite as first option, and then some birds. I'm not sure if it a problem of the Makefile (some missing library?), but I've also tried with static linking (updated Makefile in my repo) and this issue remains. Could you try to classify this image and check that the output is consistent?

Yes, I met the same problem as @piiswrong , the predict result of c_api seems not very stable. 
Even most of the time it shows the same result with the same image, but sometimes it shows differently. 
I do not know if it is a bug or just my miss unstanding with the c api.

Usually non-deterministic results (different outputs from the same input) are due to linkage issues, typically missing libraries. For instance, when using MKL in C++ it is necessary to add many extra flags and libs. So maybe the Makefile is wrong. I can't check it this week, but I'll try to do it ASAP.
When I used Theano, some layers with random noise, such as the dropout layer, will make the result non-deterministic. So make sure it is not the reason of your problem.
Good point @zhangchen-qinyinghua, I'll also check this
You mean setting an parameter accordingly or coding this function to that layer. But how does indeption net predict on a single image in predict-with-pretrained-model.ipynb ?

@zhangchen-qinyinghua Thanks for the good job, can you please send another PR to cleanup the code style to Google C++ style, and use lint check as in scripts/lint.py to pass the lint?  It is great to make everything in consistent style

Thanks!
All the parameters  of `mx.model` resides in are on cpu and will be copied to GPU before training and copied back after it finishes. This makes things easier to load  GPU trained models into CPU.
I believe you are using too large learning rate. try learing_rate = 0.01
You want to turn `is_train=False` for test time prediction, and it should work for any batch size

please be a bit more specific, e.g. what is the configuration you use which could be helpful to give others more context. Usually accuracy goes down when you have bad initialization, or too large learning rate.

Thanks for the good job, can you please make a pass on code style to make it consistent with rest of the project ?  i.e. Google's C style.

Check the  `lint` job in main Makefile, which can help auto checks the code style

Thanks!

@were I am going to close this issue for now. Can you open another issue with a small snippet that reproduces your problem? We can take a look. The accuracy measure was only defined for more probability output of each class, so not 1d vector

You can pass pre-initialized weight into  Feedforward as in 

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L479

The Feedforward is a thin wrapper of  NDArray and initialization happens here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L540 You can do arbitrary operations you like to initialize the ndarrays like in this function. Either by reusing initializer class, or do your own initialization
This happens to me on some machines as well and I do not know what was the cause, but since python process occured, it should run without a problem
So simply ignoring the message should be fine
fixed by https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/900

@tqchen Thank you tianqi :)

I've found the problem of the inconsistent output. OpenCV data array is stored as BGR,BGR,BGR, whereas MXPredSetInput expects the array as RRRRRR...,GGGGGGG...,BBBBBBB.... I've updated my code in https://github.com/pertusa/mxnet_predict_cc accordingly and now it works. @tqchen, could you please change your loop in getMeanFile?

About the non-deterministic output, dropout layers give some random values as @zhangchen-qinyinghua commented. This is not a serious issue as the expected results are usually quite similar but some frameworks like Caffe have some layers that can be discarded int the TEST phase (usually dropouts). I wonder if there is something similar in MXNet, but if not it could be a good feature.

OK, let me reproduce my problem.

Thank you for helping me a lot.

The examples in image-classification now all use kvstore (which I think should be fxied). You can get into the update_on_kvstore=False path by calling Feedforward.fit(kvstore=None)

Overall I like this design. I have been thinking about refactoring this for a while but haven't got the time to do it. Thank you so much for your contribution!

Hi piiswrong, thanks for the quick respond. 

Did you mean the multi_output parameter?

I noticed it before. I do not think it is doing the same thing. For example, once multi_output is set to be true, the input data to the SoftmaxOutput is assumed to be a n x k x (x1,...,xn) dimensional input, instead a regular n x (x1,...,xn). Anyway, the case I am referring to is where you do not need to change the shape of input data matrix but that of the label matrix (from n x 1 to n x K).

Anyway, there might be a possibility that the multi_output parameter way and my implementation is fundamentally doing the same thing, but I highly doubt about it. Therefore, at least for the problem I mentioned above, the multi_output way, is either not doing the same thing or implemented in a less elegant way where you have to duplicate the input data K times. 

I might be wrong because I did not went through it carefully, let me know your ideas.
I see what you mean. For multi target prediction, you can simply create n softmax symbols with the same input.

@jimxinbo  I believe the standard way to solve multi-label problem is to use logistic loss, i.e. each output is a {0,1} so that for each instance you can have multiple outputs = 1. See e.g. http://arxiv.org/pdf/1312.5419v3.pdf
Was it related to the libmxnet.so file?

I don't think currently mxnet supports this feature. To give you a temporary solution, you can allocate a (batch_size, embedding_dimension) matrix using mxnet. And use numpy yourself to do whatever you want (taking multiple rows in numpy is easy) and just do something like:

```
exec.embed[:] = np.sum(W[ind,:], axis=0)
```

. Then just train the model and everytime you call backward(), you need to update the numpy parameters by yourself.

@zhangchen-qinyinghua @piiswrong If I compiled the program with libmxnet.so in the mxnet/lib/ folder, then the program would get this error:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7029845/11762724/abf70642-a0be-11e5-8701-d74b5f124d05.png)

If I compiled it without libmxnet.so in the folder mxnet/lib/ (i moved it to another directory for python), then it would happen with the error I mentioned before.

I believe this could be the problem. The registered Operators should be in the dynamic library, which is more reasonable structure. So it is unreasonable for me to compile the code without the .so file in the mxnet/lib/ folder...

I am not sure whether this is the problem...If it is, how to solve it with the error of the image I showed?

Hi @Kublai-Jing, thanks for the suggestion. Yes, you are right. The standard understanding of softmax is exactly to use this 1-of-K coding (name from PRML) where for each class, you have a {0,1} indicator. This can be easily generalized to multi-labels in the way as you mentioned. I derived the backprop accordingly. But from an implementation perspective, it maybe more desirable to use a label matrix of n x K instead of n x C (e.g. maybe C =1000, and K = 5). Of course when K is not fixed, your way is necessary. (I actually did implement it first in the way of 1-of-K coding, but were bothered by a big n x C matrix and turned to my current one.) Anyway, good point.

I think @piiswrong 's suggestion is a nice way to get around and allow us to work with multi-label using the current mxnet layers. The only weak point is that we will need to do K times of Forward passing where only one is necessary. This may or may not be a big deal. I am not sure.

I see what you mean. But each forward pass you still get C-way softmax, and you need to do it K times, which is more expansive then just doing it once. The only advantage is that the input label matrix is at lower memory cost (as you mentioned, you only need NxK label matrix, not NxC). I myself probably would not think that is a good strategy. Also, from optimization standpoint, Softmax will push up the value of the target, and push down others. Yes you do it K times to ensure that each target value gets to be pushed up. But still there is some gradients that try to push down the target values, even though it really shouldn't be. Don't know if this is clear: 

Say K = 2, C = 10  Take one data point (x, y) where y = (1,4)
You will get gradients that try to raise the value of 1 and 4. But when you do a forward pass on y = 1, there is gradient that tries to push down 4, and vice versa.

Perhaps I did not make myself clear. 

We can do only one forward pass using using a N x K label matrix, this is what I did in my self-coded layer. All I am saying is that piiswrong's suggestion by using K (currently available) softmax layers will need to do K times of forward pass.

Regarding the gradient-push-down issue, I think you have a good intuition here. I also had this concern when I saw piiwrong's suggestion (of using K different softmax layers). But once you go into the math derivation, you will see it is actually equivalent. This is because the backprop gradient will be a summation of all the backprop from each labeled class and there is no explicit push down as you might imagined. Please check out the current way they implement softmax and you will probably see what I am saying here.

Anyway, I am pretty sure that my current implementation work correctly and in an memory efficient manner (one forward one backward and using only N x K memory). I am trying to be objective by saying that @piiswrong 's suggestion will work and allow us to use currently available layers. But for sure I am not a big fun of it and I think K time of forward passing is a bit wasteful.

How about use different branch, such as v3, v4?
Then the v3 branch will basically stop developing. Since v4 didn't change the interface much from v3, we can make it easier for people with a very low cost. I think it's worth it.
Or USE_CUDNN and USE_CUDNN_v3 and make v4 the default
I would prefer compile time flags, with CUDNNv4 being the default.
